My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
This is in reply to your personal request of May 9 concerning
material relating to yellow fever in Cuba.

Thus far nothing has been found relative to Camp Lazear or
the renting of San Jose Farm. We have not found the spot map of
yellow fever cases made by Dr. Roger Post Ames in 1900.

Mr Jerome Monases

When an Army hospital is closed (abandoned) all retained records
must be shipped to the A.G.O.

When the Columbia Barracks Hospital was closed (1902 or 1903) those
records must have been shipped, i.e. par. 1-3 below.

head.hi: LIST OF RECORDS TO SEARCH FOR

list.item:
(1) Sick and wounded reports (retained) (very important). It is im-
portant to find the entry in August 1900, regarding Dean for that month
and also his entry for September (yellow fever). Carroll's sick record
also, (Sept. and Oct. 1900) Camp Lazear cases December, 1900, February
1901. (Columbia Barracks Hospital Report).

(2) Medical History of the post. This was a book in which the
Surgeon noted, usually in his own writing, any unusual events that had
transpired, in a medical way, during the month. Photos were often in-
cluded. That book, if in existence, may give valuable information.

(7) The Library of Congress for publications of Army reports of

(10) A careful search of the Army Medical Library for other documents
on yellow fever and possibly for Reed's retained personal records. When
he died his office records must have been preserved and placed somewhere
and whoever handled them must have realized their importance and may have
put them in the Library or S.G.O. I don't think that a thorough search
for them has ever been made. The Army Medical School might have them,
but I doubt it. I doubt if Reed ever took such things to his home. Gener-
al Reed could tell you of this.

(11) Among people to consult I suggest that you write General F.F.
Russell at the Harvard Medical School, Boston, Mass. Steward John
Neate worked in Russell's laboratory in Washington for a long time
and he may be able to tell you something that Neate told him about
his work with Reed in Cuba.

div1.p:
Col. Garrison is dead, but he was a close friend of Reed's.
Garrison wrote much of the text in Mrs. Sternberg's biography of Gen-
eral Sternberg.

Others who know much of the story are General Ireland, General
C. R. Reynolds and some of the older professors at Johns Hopkins.
Don't forget the Welch Library.

Has Mrs. Lazear any more letters?
I support Kean's letter & mine to her are not
in existence. I think they would show our
feelings about Lazear's work and the importance
of his discovery- Of course I do not know
what I wrote to her, but I have always felt
that my real sympathy for Mrs. L. was perhaps
not expressed as well as it should have been
because I tried to tell her how much
his discovery meant. I never heard
